intro: Phacelia neomexicana var. pseudoarizonica, commonly known as the Arizona phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptation to drought conditions. Its leaves are alternate and often have a fuzzy texture, contributing to its unique appearance. This variety is also noted for its role in supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
